translated: Jātaka
Pañcakanipāta
Maṇikuṇḍalavagga
Sujāta Jātaka
“Why are you crying,
having pulled up the green grass;
You are eating, eating, you say,

analyzed: gata sattam jaraggava  na hi annena pānena
translated: the dead stump of a bamboo tree.🔽For a cow that has died
cannot be revived by food and drink;
But you are crying in vain,
just as a fool would.”
“The head remains as it was,
as do the hands, feet, and hair;
The ears remain as they were,

analyzed: maññe goṇaḥ samuṭṭhahe  nevayyakassa sīsam ca
translated: I think the cow will get up.🔽The head and limbs of the dead
are not seen;
You are crying over a lump of clay,
aren’t you just a fool?”
“I am truly on fire,

original: ghatasittaṁva pāvakaṁ;🔽Vārinā viya osiñcaṁ,🔽sabbaṁ nibbāpaye daraṁ.
analyzed: pāvaka  vārinā viyaḥ osiñca  sabbam nibbāpaye dara
translated: like a pot placed on the fire;🔽You have sprinkled me with water,🔽and extinguished all my grief.
The dart has been pulled out
that was lodged in my heart;

analyzed: yaḥ me soka paretassa  pitu sokam apānudi
translated: That which for me, overcome with grief,🔽removed my grief for my father.
I have been pulled out from the dart,
free from grief, clear,
I do not grieve or cry,
having heard you, young brahmin.”
The wise act in this way,
those who are compassionate;
They turn away from sorrow,
just as Sujāta did for his father.”
The Sujāta Jātaka is the second.
